messages.message:
Also, in this video, you can see its getting the first 2 elements correctly. But when I add a third it ‘forgets’ the first 2 elements and only returns the third. If I ignore this and keep adding more, it then sometimes remembers them again


https://www.loom.com/share/13df3df1f3454552806d50a28fa1c801?sid=3eb0d351-4242-4f35-a338-9e23c7b2e8b5
Also the output table should be in the same order that the elements were added to the configuration
And its possible to get strange output like this
the last issue with the incorrectly formatted table seems to be a frontend bug, so i’ll try to reproduce this after we have the sample file

@Lee thanks for flagging! If you edit the attributes, we re run the whole field in the backend, so the LLM tries to extract from scratch. the LLM is looking for all the requested attributes at the same time, so adding/removing/editing the attributes can impact the overall extraction, not just the attribute which has changed. I will try to experiment with making attributes more isolated. In the mean time, I will recommend adding descriptions to your attributes for best results.

@Serena the pipeline returns a list of dictionaries, so ordering within each dict is not preserved, and all keys are not guaranteed. This is quite easily fixable though, is it required for some functionality?

I think it’s unexpected for the user to add attributes 1, 2, 3 and then see them returned in a different order. It’s implied that the user is defining a JSON schema by adding attributes, so they would expect their attribute “schema” to be preserved
